newsitem.title: USA: Estimated $13.5 billion flowed to stock funds in April.
newsitem.headline: Estimated $13.5 billion flowed to stock funds in April.

text.p: Investors embraced stock mutual funds in April, spurning low-yielding bond and income funds, but caution ruled amid fears that the stock market rally would fizzle, an industry group and analysts said on Thursday.
At the same time, more aggressive stock funds appear to be making a comeback, as the scare from last month's stock sell-off is wearing off, they said.
Investors poured an estimated $13.5 billion into stock mutual funds in April, up from $10.5 billion in March, the Investment Company Institute (ICI) said.
In the first few days of May, investors snatched up conservative mutual funds, and overall cash flows are primed to beat April totals, according to fund companies.
At the same time, the ICI said the estimated flow to bond and income funds was nil last month after investors withdrew $1.99 billion in March.
"If we hold this daily pace for all of May, it will be the fastest pace on record," said Gavin Quill, vice president of marketing for Scudder Investor Services Inc.
For the first five days of May, Scudder saw inflows of $76 million compared with $187 million for all of April -- a daily rate of about $15 million vs. $9 million in April, he said.
"May is on track to be about the same as April or stronger," said Brian Mattes, a spokesman at Vanguard Group.
Quill said "the area of greatest focus" is its conservative growth and income fund, which has accounted for nearly 50 percent in equity flows so far this month.
"Index funds are out in front. The 500 Portfolio fund is still a frontrunner," said Mattes of Vanguard.
However, investors are also becoming more aggressive.

"There's been a dramatic shift within the first week to more aggressive funds," said Tracey Gordon, a spokeswoman at Charles Schwab Corp. "The laggards for the first quarter are suddenly performing extremely well."
Schwab posted net inflows of $174 million into aggressive growth funds for the first seven days of this month compared with $32 million for all of April.
Growth funds had inflows of $252 million for the first days of May vs. $129 million for all of April, Gordon said.

Massachusetts Financial Services Co. said the conservative Massachusetts Investors Trust, the country's oldest fund, and MFS Research Fund, a mid-cap growth fund, both benefited from large inflows this month.
"Large-cap growth and income and growth funds are the most popular so far this month," said Jim Folwell, a market analysis manager at MFS.
Analysts noted that while the April estimates were higher than the March results they were still far below the flows in April 1996.
"A year ago, the stock market was a lot more accomodating than it was this year," said Susan Paluch, managing editor of the Morningstar Investor newsletter. "That's certainly having an effect."
Analysts also noted that new fund investors, scared by the stock market's volatility, have sought refuge in safer money market funds.
The ICI's monthly estimates are derived from unpublished weekly estimates based on a survey of long-term funds that account for about 97 percent of long-term mutual fund assets, the ICI said.
